pageContext.claim: “I would call the Crown Prince and I'd say, "You got to help us out. You got to get some more." And, all of a sudden, the oil starts flowing and the gasoline prices are down. No other President can do that. No other President was able to do that, or maybe they didn't try. But I've done it. So now they're under attack, and we will work something out with them.”
pageContext.analysis: The president has little power to move prices at the gas pump in any direction because they depend on market forces beyond his control. A variety of market factors has contributed to the falling price of gasoline, including Trump's announcement of new sanctions on Iran to choke off its oil sales. Trump previously claimed prices fell because of phone calls to foreign leaders in oil-rich countries. But according to the authoritative Lundberg Survey of U.S. fuel markets, the national average climbed 9.57 cents per gallon between Sept. 13 and Sept. 27. "Part of that nearly 10-cent retail price hike came from U.S. refining problems," the report said.
